H1299 cells were transfected with siRNA duplexes targeting Mcl-1, Bak and EGFP. knockdown of either Bak or Mcl-1 renders minimal, if any, effects on replication and transcription of IBV RNA. no consistent trends of increase/decrease of viral RNA were observed in Bak and Mcl-1 knockdown cells infected with IBV. the contrary was observed in the culture medium of infected cells over-expressing Mcl-1. overexpression of myc-Mcl-1 significantly inhibited the replication of IBV in H1299 cells. these results confirm respective roles Mcl-1 and Bak play in regulating the rate of both IBV-induced apoptosis and viral progeny release. up-regulation of Bak and Mcl-1 may play essential roles in maintaining balance between life and death of infected cells. this points to the importance of these two members of the Bcl2 gene family in regulating IBV-induced apoptosis. up-regulation of Mcl-1 in IBV-infected cells may represent an effective host anti-coronavirus response that regulates viral infectivity and productivity. the down-regulation observed during late stages of virus infection may be due to the rapid degradation of the protein. however, it is apparent that viral replication is required for the up-regulation of these two genes at the transcriptional level. the induction of Mcl-1 protein in IBV-infected cells is indeed affected by the activation of MEK and/or PI3K pathways, as well as by upstream activators such as the transcriptional regulator of ER-stress mediated apoptosis. the observed up-regulation of GADD153 in this study would lend further support to this conclusion. poptotic viral genes can be harnessed as vectors and targeted to tumor cells as a potential anti-cancer therapeutic benefit. degenerative diseases such as Alzheimer's disease and Huntingdon's disease may also be similarly treated with anti-apoptotic viral genes.
